docs.lead_paragraph: In a courtroom where at least two terminally ill patients watched, both of them strong supporters of Oregon's assisted-suicide law, lawyers for the federal government told a federal judge today that Oregon doctors could and should be barred from helping such people hasten their deaths with lethal medicines. Four months after Attorney General John Ashcroft issued a directive intended to overturn the law, Judge Robert E. Jones of Federal District Court here heard final arguments in the emotional legal battle over the Oregon law, which voters have approved twice. Oregon is the only state that sanctions assisted suicide.

headline.main: Government and Oregon Vie Over Doctor-Aided Suicide

docs.abstract: Judge Robert E Jones hears final arguments over Oregon's assisted-suicide law; at least two terminally ill patients watch proceedings, both of them strong supporters of assisted-suicide law; lawyers for federal government argue that Oregon doctors could and should be barred from helping such people hasten their deaths with lethal medicines; Oregon voters have approved measure twice; photo (M)
docs.snippet: In a courtroom where at least two terminally ill patients watched, both of them strong supporters of Oregon's assisted-suicide law, lawyers for the federal government told a federal judge today that Oregon doctors could and should be barred from...

docs.lead_paragraph: When a bitterly divided Congress failed to pass an economic stimulus bill last fall, many predicted the recession would only worsen. But while few were paying attention, government spending surpassed the amounts envisioned in the stimulus measure, exceeding what even the most vociferous advocates wanted. The unexpected surge -- along with the remarkable strength in consumer spending -- helps to explain why the recession, to nearly everyone's surprise, has been so mild and may be ending.

headline.main: Sharp Rise in Federal Spending May Have Helped Ease Recession

docs.abstract: Unexpected surge in government spending--along with remarkable strength in consumer spending--helps to explain why recession in US has been been so mild and may be ending; surge in government spending, which started in October, has continued into March at rate of more than $100 billion; income tax cuts that went into effect at beginning of this year are expected to provide further lift to economy; photo; chart (L)
